user_review: Beautifully atmosphere for a special night out.  We got the tasting menu and the portions were thoughtful and appropriate.  We also received complimentary amuse bouche both with our appetizer and dessert. The wait staff were attentive and knowledgeable.  The risotto was amazing with the Parmesan foam. The beef tartare is perfections.  Although, I was not a fan of the butternut squash dessert - the chocolate lava cake is the way to go.

When you feel like luxury, but not necessarily going to a hot spot, this is the place for you. My wife took me here for a birthday lunch and the entire experience was awesome.We started at the bar which was ideal for people watching. Within a span of 15 minutes, I got into 2 expertly prepared Vesper Martinis with a twist of orange. They were spectacular. I'd go back to the bar just for this drink. I got to see a dejected older man being scolded by his disinterested trophy wife, followed by her staring at her phone for 10 minutes straight without a single word exchanged between them. Both of them looked f!@#ing miserable. Who says money buys happiness? I also noticed what looked like a pimp with a gaggle of young women off in the corner ordering some rare bottles of wine. You've got a couple of businessmen to my left ordering Old Fashioneds. One of them asks the bartender why his drink doesn't have a cherry in it. She tells him that he's thinking of a Manhattan, but if he needs a cherry, one will be provided for him.Eventually, we moved to a table in the bright covered terasse overlooking the garden. Brian Mulroney walks by, and is greeted by the waiter "Hello Mr Prime Minister" The guy at the table across from us is wearing a baseball cap. Another table of country club types look like they belong in a Brooks Brothers catalogue or a commercial for cholesterol medication. Ultimately, the restaurant is a mix between people treating themselves to something special, and others who have long ceased being impressed by the nice things in life.I started with the Iberico Ham appetizer which comes at a price tag of a whopping 46$ (it was my birthday after all......) Unfortunately, the meat was sliced into tiny little squares and lacked any of the rich taste you would find at Ibericos on St. Denis or Pied de Cochon on Duluth. That's fine though. Sipping my funky orange wine, I was feeling NO PAIN. Add to that one heck of an epic bread basket and butter, life was good. Then came the burger that Lesley Chesterman ranked in her top 10. I wholly agree. It's one tasty burger. I would have preferred a slightly thicker patty, however. Purely on taste, I'll take the 7 dollar burger at Burger de Ville any day over that of the Ritz. Nevertheless, for 31$, you get the atmosphere and the experience.For dessert, I decided to get the cheese plate, which was tasty but underwhelming in it's portion. For my birthday, they also presented me with a basket of freshly baked madeleines which were seriously addictive.For a moment, I can fantasize about becoming a regular here, living upstairs and spending money with a bored look on my face. On second thought, it's the perspective of everyday life that makes an occasional splurge at a place like Maison Boulud fun.

Maison Boulud came highly recommended, so we spontaneously decided to splurge after having a delayed flight. Everything about the establishment was beautiful, and the service was top-notch (honestly expected nothing less). Opted for the pre-fixe menu, and thoroughly enjoyed the choices and every single dish that came out. I definitely recommend it since you get a pretty comprehensive experience out of it. Just make sure to allot about two hours for it. The cocktails were also really good, so don't forget to grab a drink while you're there!

My first time at the Ritz Carlton Hotel resto-Maison Boulud was a truly memorable experience. From the moment I walked in, service is on you- I checked in my coat and was walked to my table. For a Sunday evening, we got lucky to be seated next to the garden -the view is beautiful. With soft music playing in the background you'll be greeted by your server. I was there trying the mushroom menu (the menu rotates weekly). I ordered the 75$ tasting that includes a selection of 4-5 appetizers, choice of one main and a set dessert. With a shared bottle of wine for 3, tax and tip- it came to around 130$ pp. Before each course, the server took their time to explain each item. Presentation was beautiful and portions were perfect. I hope to come back to this lovely elegant piece of Montreal soon!

For our anniversary, the hubby surprised me to a fancy gourmet 3-course brunch at Maison Boulud. Stepping inside, I would have never expected such gorgeous interior and luxury hidden away in downtown Montreal's Golden Square Mile - it really felt like walking into somewhere in London's Mayfair. We were seated on the patio which was flooded with natural light and a spectacular view of the beautiful Ritz garden. The ambiance is romantic and tranquil, almost as if the hustle and bustle of the city is non-existent. The season's menu was presented to us, which changes as it is influenced by the seasonal bounties from Quebec and uses local ingredients. Despite there not being many vegetarian options, we still found it difficult deciding on our choices. For the first course, I enjoyed the Organic Beets, Monnoir Cheese, Pistachio, Wild Caraway starter which was light and full of flavour, awakening the taste buds to what would come next.I opted for the Spinach and Cheddar Stuffed Croissant for my main course; though it does not sound as unique and exciting as the other options, I can honestly say that this was the BEST breakfast croissant that I have ever had. Every bite was full of flavour and so filling; pastry lovers - this is the one for you. The husband had Eggs Benedict with Chanterelles Mushrooms and he was definitely more than satisfied with his choice. The level of presentation definitely matched the taste, we were both in heaven.Finally, for my favourite course (dessert) this was by far, the most difficult to choose from. With so many unique pairings, it was hard to bring it down to just one selection. I decided on the Quebec Strawberry Clafoutis served with Sweet Clover Mousse, Blackberries and Vanilla Ice Cream; by far, this was the best course and in my opinion, the best selection too. Breaking into the sweet mousse to discover the delightful berry filling was a such a treat; alongside the buttery clafoutis, each bite was heavenly and bursting with flavour and freshness. Hubby had Olive Oil candied Apricots with Vanilla Mousse, Saffron and Sorbet - the menu barely gives any indication as to what to expect, so to see it presented as a dark chocolate dessert surrounded by pieces of saffron jelly and candied apricots was a magnificent surprise! Presentation truly is immaculate, we loved the extra touches of candles and chocolate wordings on our plates. By its fine interior, the Ritz Carlton definitely lived up to its reputation and legendary chef Daniel Boulud lived up to his name. With such top class service and speciality crafted brunch, Maison Boulud truly is a 5-star culinary experience!

So we found out that the Ritz Montreal is the "Orginal aka O.G." of North America. Naturally I wanted to check the property out because I am Marriott Ambassador and love the brand.The Maison Boulud is connected to the hotel and my Uber driver raved about their outdoor seating area the night before which intrigued my wife. We ordered a three course meal and shared it. It was definitely enough for two people. I had a bottle sparking water as well.First off the outdoor seating area is absolutely beautiful! If the weather is nice you forsure want to sit outside, It was June 30th ( summatime) and the weather was perfect. Food was spectacular as expected ( very pricy) and the service was too notch.I give this place two  's up

Everything we tried looked like a piece of art and was very unique. We got Foie gras as an appetizer, which had a jelly layer and pieces of sponge cake on top. I ve tried foie gras many times in the past, nothing close this this, simply amazing.John Dory fish entre was a white breaded fish with small pieces of roasted cauliflower and broccoli with light flavorful sauce spread over it. Onglet - hanger steak was perfectly cooked and served with a delicious thin gravy sauce on the side. Dessert was a heaven- we tried hazelnut cake and maple ice cream dessert, cant recall the exact names, both were just to die for. The wine selection was also very good both  by the glass or bottle. I tried red meinklung blaufrankisch and it turned out to be a good discovery.

We thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at Maison Boulud. The service was wonderful, and the food and drinks were excellent. We had the razor clams appetizer, the nimbus and grande madame cocktails,  a few glasses of wine, the scallop entree and the steak entree with potatoes and vegetables as a side, and the lava cake for dessert, and all exceeded our expectations. The bread was delicious as well, and we appreciated the gift from the chef we were given after dessert. It may be worth noting that the menu wasn't exactly as it appeared online (the lamb we saw online was replaced with another option on the menu at the restaurant). The atmosphere was lovely as well, and I'd certainly recommend this restaurant for a special night out.

Boulud needs no introduction and this review is just to validate that it is in fact worth the price. This is the most extravagant meal I've ever eaten. My friends and I did the 8 course tasting menu with wine pairing and I don't even know where to begin.Each dish was better than the next. There was a lot of fish and seasonal ingredients which I really enjoyed. With each service, the sommelier poured us our wine pairing and took a couple of minutes to explain to us her selection. I loved the variety of drinks that we were brought! We started with a champagne, then a white wine, a sake, an orange wine and finally a red wine. Our meal consisted of:-amuse bouche-octopus and scallop crude with a jus-snow crab and avocado with a yuzu sauce and salty rice cracker (this was my favourite dish!)-foie gras with homemade brioche-spaghetti with clams and sea urchin sauce (amazing, my other favourite dish!)-lamb with cauliflower purée and vegetables-cheese dish made of a quebec cheese on a cracker with poached pears covered with shaved cheese-dessert were 2 deconstructed apples. One had poached apples with chantilly and the other a sorbet inside!-we also had mignardises with coffee. They brought a selection of sablés, chocolate truffles and apple jelly squares.It truly was a very special experience and one that I will not forget it!

This is a brunch review, and I usually hate reading brunch reviews as they don't tell you very much about a restaurant like this, so I'll keep it short.Bottom line is that I wouldn't be reviewing Maison Boulud's brunch if it was not extraordinary, and it most certainly is. From the serene environment (an idyllic duck pond, a lush garden, objets d'art galore) to the impeccably respectful and knowledgeable service staff to (most importantly) the food, this was a meal that needed to be written about.The "Saumon Fumé Maison Et Oeuf Au Plat" consisted of a mound of smoked salmon, a sunny-side up egg set on top of potato latkes, and a dollop of crème fraiche with dill, red onions, and capers. There's nothing revolutionary with this dish except that every single component was perfectly cooked, cut, or otherwise prepared. Do you like your crème fraiche to taste like otherworldly onion butter? Then this is for you, as it was for me. They could have stopped here and still earned 5 stars, but it got even better.The "Homard en Brioche" (Lobster Roll) used an especially eggy brioche roll set against a surprisingly spicy fresh lobster salad with crisp cucumbers and celery - with the heat coming from pickled red radishes. Dressed to the 9s with seasoned frisée lettuce tossed in oil, it was evident that whoever conceived this dish is in love with the kind of lobster rolls served in toasted hot dog buns at seaside New England clam shacks, but saw opportunities to tweak them in an effective way that enhances rather than subverts.My brunch ended with the "Forêt Noir," a black forest chocolate génoise with chocolate mousse, cherries in kirsch, chantilly cream, vanilla ice cream, and sprinkled with flakes of gold. A sad and sobering send-off, as I realized while eating it that it will be months, if not years, before I make it back to Montréal from San Diego for my next meal at Maison Boulud.Food/Décor/Service: 4.6/4.9/4.7What To Order: Homard en Brioche (Lobster Roll), Saumon Fumé Maison Et Oeuf Au Plat (Smoked Salmon, Latkes, Egg)

If you wanna treat yourself to a champagne laced, fancy brunch, this is the place to do it. It's located in the gorgeous Ritz. Ask for the patio seating. It's absolutely breathtaking with the bright natural sunlight and freshly fallen snow.I'd definitely recommend coming hungry and indulging in the three course brunch. The mimosas are perfectly fizzy and I love the pulpy freshly squeezed OJ they use. The complimentary warm bread to start is incredible. What's even better? The rich butter it comes with! The chicken liver pate and smoked salmon were both hits. The lobster Benedict was worth every extra CAD. The desserts were incredible - the waffles were properly leavened and served with the most delicious vanilla whipped cream and of course, maple syrup!The waitstaff is incredibly kind and personable. Overall a fantastic experience and would come back time and time again!

Sure I'm going to go to Maison Boulud and the Ritz and have a cocktail!  Doesn't everybody?I can only speak for the cocktails.They were okay, not spectacular, but good ...and slanting more to the great side.Would say that the staff does go out of their way, to make sure the customer is happy.FIVE STARS for Service.4 stars for the DecorSeems like mostly tourists and people over 65 years of age go to this place.  Not my kind of place.  I felt uncomfortable, as I do not dress like a tourist and I do not "hang" with tourists.I might have had a better experience if I was with a group of friends.

Maison Boulud lives up to its​ namesake icon. With our culinary legends dropping off the face of the planet these days at the same rate as musicians I have started to make it a point to visit as many Michelin rated Chef outposts as possible while I can. With Joël no longer with us, most would argue​ Daniel Boulud is now the North American ambassador of French and in a city with a name such as Montréal, there was zero chance that I would not visit. What is interesting​ about Maison Boulud would have escaped me had I not consulted with Canada's own legend of Yelp - Soleil S. - before my visit. Apparently,​ Boulud was forced to do an about-face​ on his business model we are accustomed to in the States as the local economy started to lose traction. With that,​ the menu transitioned​ from Classic French to a more accessible hybrid that does not shake the wallet so hard. The bill will still sting a bit, however. Having been to several other Boulud forums, this actually​ made the stop all the more special. The ​menu is driven by Québec's regional​ purveyors and you will discover​ specialties from Boulud's New York City restaurants, including Lyonnais Charcuterie, Acorn Fed Senorio Iberico Ham, and even some casual items you would never have thought possible such as Burgers & Pasta dishes - and of course - several plates you can only find in Montréal.Case in point would have to be Maison Boulud's Croque-Monsieur which takes a rather humble French Sandwich into the stratosphere​ with the use of superlative ingredients. I know it has been done before (Tom Keller's Bouchon comes to mind) but not quite to these heights. Two​ pieces of bakery fresh Pullman loaf Bread is loaded inside and out with ​healthy heaps of Curé Hebert Cheese which gives the dish a smooth, velvety​ texture that is comparable​ to custard along with a nutty flavor that contrasts perfectly with the generous​ thinly shaved Ham. Speaking about the Ham, being a Boulud recipe it cannot just be pasture raised, grass-fed​ Jambon de Paris. No, no, no. Nothing less than Suckling Pig will do. Easily the best Croque-Monsieur I have ever had. By a long shot. Add in the tony locale inside the Ritz Carlton on Montréal's Golden Mile, an interior that would be at home in Paris or New York City, and a polished service game and you have a 5-star rating for the masses. This is a notch you want on the culinary belt.

Deserves 5 stars, but the blue fin tuna tasted horribly fishy, ruining his review.One of the nicest restaurants I've set foot in. The place is absolutely incredible, it feels like you have entered a world of perfect luxury.The service was incredible, the moment you step in, everything so far worthy of 5 stars.The food was perfect (main course) and actually bad (starter)I got the blue fin tuna carpaccio to start. I'm not an expert and don't claim to be, but I have tasted lots of amazing fresh fish. This blue fin tuna tasted VERY fishy, so much that I'm typing this an hour after I've come home from the restaurant and still taste fish in my mouth.For the main course I got  pigeon done three ways; roasted, pate, and foie gras. This was one of the best dishes I have ever eaten. Every bite was rich, bursting with deep delicious flavours and was just down right fun to eat.Everything about this place deserves 5 stars, if it wasn't for that damn blue fin tuna!!

Excellent lunch and a nice place to have a business meeting.  One of the best in Montreal.  You unfortunately do not have too many places like this in the US but then again this is Montreal-- the best food city in North America, certainly the highest number of top restaurants per capita...

One of the best dinner places to eat in Montreal, hands down. I haven't tried their brunch yet, nor lunch, but dinner was spectacular.We took the tasting menu, and tried everything on there (we shared).I realized in these restaurants (we also went to Marcus and loved it), that you should always order the vegetarian plates because they are OUTSTANDING in these places.The ravioli of the night was vegetarian, we never would have taken it, it was "forced" upon us as a menu item, but it was our favourite dish. Incredible, incredible food.The rest was equally as good. The only downside if any was the salmon, mostly because I think I don't really enjoy black chickpeas or chickpeas in general, and I didn't really like the overall flavour of the dish. It was all beautifully prepared but I don't like those flavours as much.Well priced too, considering the quality, and we even got free little amuse bouches and ending to the dinners. It was calm, relaxing, not too loud, warm, and an excellent dining experience.I am definitely coming back here.
High class cuisine, Very cozy place, very professionnel staff, I enjoyed my evening very much

Although Maison Boulud is not Daniel in NYC, it was a wonderful experience. We went for the tasting menu on a hot Friday night and scored a table on the patio. It was wonderful. First we thought about the wine pairing. Then we thought, six glasses with eight courses is a lot. Then I wondered how I can pick wine when I don't know what's coming. The waitress and sommelier were wonderful. They suggested wines by the glass that would hold up for at least two upcoming courses. Not all choices hit my preferences perfectly, but they all worked. I just have strange preferences. On the surprise menu, I made clear that there are few ingredients that I do not like - and one is in season - but not for me please. No problem. They checked with the kitchen and concluded that an adaptation to my preferences is no problem. I don't have a reference, but it was heavenly. Foie gras terrine, sashimi (I think fluke) wit radish, spaghetti vongole, lamb, and various desserts is all I can recall, but there were more than eight. Now we need to send the staff of Bar Boulud Boston to Maison Boulud Montreal for training! Why does Boston get neglected?

Very disappointing.  We chose a Sunday brunch her for the full ritz Carlton experience.  We found it to be average at best and for ritz, that's just not good enough.  You expect to pay a premium but to also be wowed.  It didn't happen.  Having to ask servers for everything throughout the brunch was frustrating.  Yes it was crowded but it's never a good excuse.  The food was good, not great.  One annoyance, the selection of wines by the glass was very limited.  Trying a few flavors is nice.  Add some options to the pages and pages of full bottles on the wine list.

Fantastic. Ate lunch here two days last week.  I had the very best burger I've ever had one day and a great club sandwich the next.  We split a bottle of Beaujolais and sat in the lovely room next to the garden.  Lovely room, great burger, loved it.

DANIEL BOULUD!This excellent restaurant is located in the Ritz-Carlton. We had a wonderful breakfast here, only the service dragged down the rating. We ate outside by the garden and I had their famous Pain Perdu (French toast) with three sauces plus Toulousaine Sausage. Wonderful! My wife had poached eggs with Smoked Gaspor Farm Ham. Also wonderful.The service was merely average. For example, I had to ask for a coffee refill. This chef has Michelin stars elsewhere, but he won't get them here unless better control & training is exercised with the staff.Location - 5 starsFood - 5 starsService - 3 starsValue - 5 starsAmbiance/Décor - 5 stars

How often do you go to a restaurant and find everything to impeccable, from the time you enter, to the time to leave. This is one of those experiences. The location is excellent. The atmosphere is fantastic. The staff is outstanding. The food is exquisite.It really is worth every penny to be able to have that kind of experience. I will be back.

I went to the Maison Boulud bar this evening for an appératif. The lounge was spacious and ritzy ;) (couldn't help myself). We sat at a nice couch and the lounge tables were far enough from each other for proper privacy. Good date spot I must say.The waiter was kind and super knowledgeable. He was sweet and smiley. I wish I could've caught his name to thank him properly. This place is definitely a spot where you do not want to look like Joe Shmo. You would stick out like a soar thumb. Instead put some lipstick and heels on (only if you wanna) and strut your stuff...besides it's always fun to dress up and make an effort once and a while.

I am reviewing the brunch experience. This is one of the classiest restaurants in Montreal and the garden in the summer is absolutely stunning. For the brunch you basically get several courses that are beautifully plated. From eggs to fish to waffles I thought everything was very good but nothing stood out as a memorable signature brunch dish.

It was my first time eating at la maison boulud and i'm seriously in love.Nothing more needs to be said...No. Seriously. It is probably the best restaurant in montreal. I'm not afraid to say it. The decor is simply spectacular and fancy. Even the chairs are massive and confortable. Service is personal, cordial, attentionate and perfectly executed. Standards are very high and impeccable.My entrée was a plate of guinea hen filled cavatellini pasta that were so tasteful. The bouillon had so much flavor I wanted to drink it by itself forever. I have some decency in public so I took a bread to get the very last drops of it but it was that good.Next was the beef tenderloin with potatoes, spinach, bone marrow and bordelaise sauce which seemed quite simple at first but it was the best, most tender and perfectly cooked tenderloin I have ever eaten. After talking with some of staff we were told that there was never any plate returned for unprecise cooking and I have no problem believing it. We were 14 people and every single dish was impeccable.To finish on another good note. We had a plate of cheese with curé-hébert and aged comté. I was full and ate the whole thing like my life depended on it. I will wait with impatience and pleasure for the moment I can return to maison boulud.

This restaurant is so fancy! I love the fire place and the outdoor covered and heated section. The service is amazing! My boyfriend and I started with a glass of bubbly each. At first I wanted a glass of rosé bubbly so they opened a magnum bottle for just one glass!!  That's nuts! So I tasted mine and tried the bubbly that my boyfriend picked and I preferred his. The waitress could tell and she said she could take the rosé bubbly back. I was hesitant but the waitress said that it was no problem so I changed it for regular champagne instead. I felt so bad but she  didn't seem to mind. Then the sommelier helped us pick a good red wine that we ended up liking a lot that was in our budget. He seemed to really know his stuff. We got the Barra (Cabernet Sauvignon).The waitress gave us these two small cheese bread rolls. They tasted like ritz crackers but in a bread format. They also gave us olive bread and cut baguette. We shared the lobster gnocchi to start. It could also be a main. This was the highlight of the night. That sauce was finger licking good! I was taking the olive bread and dipping it in what was left of the sauce. For mains we shared the beef duo and the lamb. Both were delicious but I think next time I would get the pasta because that lobster gnocchi really blew  my mind. The beef duo consisted of two rectangular pieces of steak and one square roast beef. Out of the two types of beef I preferred the roast beef. The lamb was very tasty. It came with eggplant, kale and mushrooms. The dessert was absolutely delicious! We got the chocolate coulant with salted caramel ice cream. As an extra they gave us these little bite sized desserts and they gave us a small jar of hazelnut chocolate to bring home. I haven't opened it yet but I imagine it's like homemade Nutella. It's pricey so it's not your everyday restaurant but I definitely recommend it for special events.

This was our bougie dinner choice of our trip to Montreal and it was also my first time doing a tasting menu! Maison Boulud, from Chef Daniel Boulud, really made a lasting impression on me. We had an 8pm reservation, and were seated out on the patio overlooking the pond area - really cute!The tasting menu is 6 courses, and the chef takes in any dietary restrictions/dislikes and sends out the courses. There is no set menu. We came in pretty hungry, and I did worry that we might leave hungry - but we left so stuffed! Some of my favorite dishes was the handmade gnocchi with lobster, the arancini amuse bouche, and the tuna tataki with clams. We also had several desserts - chocolate souffle was delicious and so was the passionfruit tartlets!Service was truly excellent. Our meal took about 3 hours so you definitely just sit and eat and get full to the max. We couldn't even finish our desserts! Beautiful hotel and space, would definitely recommend!

It doesn't matter what you choose from this seasonally changing menu. Everything is amazing. The fall menu had just arrived so there are more comfort food items to choose from as the weather cools.  As an entree I took the razor clam, dungeness crab and sea urchin plate. It was dabbled with dashi gelée and an avocado roll with shima aji. Wow! Light and fresh. Also tried the terrine de foie gras which was surprisingly light as well but still rich. Accompanied by a Pinot noir it went down very easy.  For the main meal I had the homemade pasta with lamb shoulder. This is comfort food at its finest. Braised vegetables and fall off the bone meat I was in heaven. My partner had the potato gnocchi with lobster. I found the lobster perfectly cooked but an odd contrast with gnocchi. The sauce that was poured on it was an elegant maitake mushroom,leek an coral emulsion that on its own would have been a soup I'd pay for. I spooned every last drop. So elegant and flavours you've never tasted married together before.  You can't resist desert at Maison Boulud... we tried the chocolate salted caramel lava cake that was so rich, I couldn't finish it. I tried! The other desert was a light strawberry pistachio limoncello baba with a scoop of basil sorbet that was to die for.  Obviously you can't eat here everyday unless you're super wealthy, but for a special occasion, you must try it. The bill for 2 is half a G, but I'm not complaining... I'm just sad I can't eat here once a week.

Mediocre in taste and service, I'd skip this and hope Montreal has better options . Had the tuna, guinea fowl and a steak plus the caprese salad. Out of all the salad was the best. Tuna was the worst of them.

Good service, great ambiance. Had the thon bluefin carpaccio as a starter, it was a bit salty for me but the lobster gnocchi was reaaaaaaaaaaal good. My favorite part was obviously the dessert Limoncello and Praline- YUM! We also got Madeleines on the house, it was super good. Will definitely go back!

We had fun dining at our first Daniel Boulud restaurant. Beautiful decor. The lunch 3 course menu was a great deal. You get lots of food for a great price. Our favorite was the chocolate dessert. My croque monsieur was good but I wish there was less bread and more cheese. Great service.

JHC. If there was a way to give a place 6 out of 5 stars, this was it. Visiting Montreal an decided to give this place a try. Could not have made a better decision. Fantastic ambiance, superb and attentive service. Had the lobster gnocchi and lamb chops. While the lobster gnocchi was quite quite delicious. The lamb chop brought a tear to my eye. I put my fork and knife down, contemplated the meaning of life before deciding if I really wanted to continue eating and finish the food. It was excellence. The dessert again, once they found out it was our anniversary, made a special plate with champagne for us. Extra points. I'm a fan for life. An will def visit again.

As one of the top rated restaurants in Montreal we arrived with high expectations.  The 8 course tasting menu did not disappoint.  Service was terrific too and overall a very pleasant experience.  The dishes were crafty, elegant, and delicious.  The meal was very pricey though and even though the food was deserved of a high price, this may have been a little too high.  More reasonably priced wine options would help too.

I went there for brunch and supper. As soon as you step into this restaurant, you feel like a VIP. One of the best service you'll get in the city. Super attentive service. I was more impressed by supper than brunch because I was hungry very shortly after brunch even though I ate a steak. Yes I know, who eats a steak for brunch? Well, me! It's on the menu so somebody has to eat it. I had a steak for supper, it was perfect so I went for more at brunch. Everything I had at this place was succulent. I like to eat in the garden, it's zen and beautiful. I didn't have their tasting menu yet but hopefully I'll get to try it soon. Obviously the place is pricey since its signed Boulud. If you want to spoil a very special someone , it's the place to be.

I have not had a bad meal at Maison Boulud. I have been to Maison Boulud for brunch and dinner. The food was excellent. The service was attentive and friendly. The ambiance was chic and upscale with a touch of old Hollywood glamour. The decor was gorgeous and worthy of being in the Ritz. On a hot summer day, the patio in the garden is an oasis. The food here is vibrant and innovative. The use of fresh ingredients and the playing of delicious flavours makes Maison Boulud a technical tour de force. One of the standout dishes was the sea urchin with a light foam. It was decadent. The prices are reasonable given the quality of the dishes. The prices are in line with similar high end restaurants. I would highly recommend Maison Boulud.

I recently had the chance to try out this resto for breakfast located in the heart of our beautiful city! My expectations were exceeded! Loved, loved everything about this well reknowned resto and it deserves 5 star rating! Let's begin with the resto ambiance..as soon as you walk into this resto you are greeted by a super friendly hostess with a great big smile! The decor is absolutely stunning and glamourous creating a warm welcoming feeling. The moment you walk in , you get a sense of being transported away! At the end of the resto is the stupendous beautifully glass covered veranda overlooking the beautiful garden and pond. Nothing like having breakfast in a beautiful glass veranda creating a zen-like feeling. Onto the food, wow ...we tried the pain perdu and egg's benedict dishes as well as a side order of smoked home and basket of four warmly baked goodies croissant, chocolatine, raspberry tartelette ....every bite just melted in your mouth. Yes the prices for some of these breakfast dishes are quite expensive but they really worth it!!  This is a great place to celebrate an anniversary, wedding proposal, birthday milestone or a girls weekend outing! I recommend trying this out at least once in a lifetime! The resto is adjacent to the luxiourious Ritz Carlton hotel! You can walk into the lobby for a sneak peek! The egg's benedict were not like any egg's benedict...the hollandaise sauce was light and delicious! Yummy!  Reservations are a must!  Simply amazing foodie experience! Check out my pictures.

The best way I can describe my experience at Maison Boulud is by acknowledging the high quality food but with a struggling atmosphere and service experience. Being connected to the Ritz Carlton helps with it's curb appeal, but once inside, the decor seems old fashioned. Greeted by a friendly staff, you feel the effort to create the sense of importance and class. The food overall is better than average but for the price point, I've had much more memorable experiences (Scramouche in Toronto, for example). Unfortunately, we had a couple of minor issues where the staff had offered to send their in house sommelier to explain the residue on the bottom of my wine glass. They never came.Overall, I'm giving a 3* because, as a high end restaurant, I expected a bit more. I will gladly revisit to give it another go in the future.

Delicious dinner our first in town. The restaurant is gorgeous, too. We had the burrata, lobster gnocchi, ravioli, and John Dory. All delicious, but especially the lobster gnocchi. Then we had fresh, hot Madeleines. To die for. The other desert (apple something) did not impress as much.

Excellent food and service. They're very accommodating. My husband and I were attracted to the same dishes, but we wanted to try a bunch of stuff instead of both taking the same dishes. So they made us each half portions. The sommeliers know their stuff. Worth the splurge.

Great ambience, the service was average,  the food was excellent. They have a good variety of wine cocktails and a very nice lunch set menu. I was disappointed of the service because it took a while before they will check on my order , then the server forgot I asked for the 3 course meal with dessert from the beginning and he still came and ask if I wanted dessert . The restaurant Location it's excellent and has a beautiful patio . The price is about right for the quality of the food, every bite had great flavor and exquisite presentation .

The food is good, flavorful and tasty. The risotto is the best I ever had. The service is excellent and accommodative. The ambiance is ok, a bit dressy, pretentious and too fake for my taste and it was noisy and difficult to hear each other. No music, thanks god. Overall it was good.

First time to Montreal. My wife and I went to this cozy restaurant in Montreal's Ritz Carlton on Sherborne St.We decided on the 5 course meal and it did not disappoint. The bread was fresh and really good. We sat at the bar and was waited on so wonderfully. Great staff! What a treat to come here!

The dining experience at Maison Boulud is very good, but not five stars as expected given the lineage and the price.  Service was perfect and the ambience was very nice.  But wine list was obnoxiously expensive with even a modest bottle running almost $200.  Fried artichokes were really good with a tasty aioli sauce.  Seafood appetizers were good, but not distinctive.  And the Cote de Beouf, while flavorful (60 day aged) was a bit undercooked and more fatty than expected.  It was a very good and enjoyable meal, but with $25+ appetizers and $50+ entrees, it should be one step more.

We ordered the 8-course tasting menu and a bottle of wine recommended by the sommelier. Every dish was exquisite (amuse-bouche, 2 appetizers, fish, pasta, meat, 2 dessert). The service was impeccable and so was the decor. If you get a chance to sit in the patio it is worth it. Highly recommend. It is located in the Ritz.
Dang... I'm not sure they gave me the royal treatment because I booked thru my Amex but this restaurant Maison Boulud in Montreal was unreal with the service and food... 6 stars!

Yes, probably 3.5 stars.  Why?  Simple - lack of value.  Ok, it's a high-end place so you're not supposed to complain about the price and have low expectations - after all you're in the Ritz Carlton.  $68 Ribeye should be charred perfectly, thick cut of beef, served hot - it wasn't (oh needed salt too).  4 fried artichokes hearts for $19 lacked a bit of acid to offset the aioli.  Duck with foie gras was well prepared but not served hot and needed salt.  The chocolate lava cake was good as were the apples, but again these were not out of this world $20 desserts (hoped for a souffle?)  Caviar choices were plentiful, but not a truffle to be found.  Our $115 bottle of wine we pretty much poured ourselves.  The wine list is extensive and the som was knowledgable, we enjoyed our super Tuscan even if he tried to sell us mediocre Canadian wine (getting a kickback I assume).  Our favorite was the bread.  The beignets (served with the burrata) and focaccia were our favorite item of the meal.  My ceviche was creative and had great flavors.  Presentation of dishes was spectacular.    So you will have a good meal here and will pay a lot for it.  While there are so many other choices for French food, I know with a bit more focus and effort, Maison Boulud could (return?) be a true 5 stars.

An exemplary experience. My parents and I went here for Saturday brunch which turned out to be one of our best decisions of our trip to Montreal. The service was sublime, waiter was kind, beaming with a smile and the servers were exceptionally well-trained so that our glasses were never empty for more than a brief moment. We were lucky enough to sit outside to enjoy the wonderful weather. You could tell the serving staff were aware of every thing happening at the table and they accomplished that without being overbearing. The food was also superb. I had the head cheese - a dish I have never had before and I am thankful that this was my introduction to its unique deliciousness - then the Icelandic Cod, which was perfectly seared and lightly seasoned. For dessert the tarte tatin was an interesting and highly sucessful interpretation of the traditional dish. It was the perfect amount of food for brunch and I left without having to adjust my belt an extra notch. Amazing experience and highly recommended.

Who would have thought that food served in a hotel restaurant could be 'I still salivate as I dream about it' worthy? Well I guess if you're the Ritz Carlton you wouldn't settle for a restaurant that didn't make Canada's top 100 list. Let alone, anything below the nb 27th spot held by La Maison Boulud!Namesake restaurant after Michelin star renowned chef Daniel Boulud, this place is probably the epitome of fine dining in Montreal... well at least from my experiences ;)Every dish is a work of art in not only presentation but in complexity of flavour. There is not a single drop of sauce that goes unnoticed for the depth of flavour it adds to the dish as a whole. That little dot of brown sauce in the lobster bisque? It's actually a reduction of mushrooms that adds an earthy element to a seafood flavoured dish. That hint of yellow you get underneath the parmesan emulsion? Yes, there is indeed lemon zest that freshens everything up.From the moment you walk in and get seated by the stunning model like hostess to the one where the waiter expertly recommends and paces your food to finally the one where you let that perfectly creamy burrata melt in your mouth ... you'll really feel like you've just experienced what Montreal and the historically luxurious Ritz had to offer in terms of the finer things in life.Granted, with finer things do come along a more pricier tag, but from time to time it's worth the splurge and La Maison Boulud falls into that category :)
Excellent local French cuisine. Superb beet salad and trout fish. French speaking only. Regards,Shaq Zaidi, MD

We had the chance to dine here.   Although the chef was originally 3 Michelin star in New York , this is not by any means comparable in Michelin service levels.  We noticed few mistakes.  We ordered our wine with the somalier.   But they didn't bring the wine even after the first 2 courses.  We had to tell them.   Table wasn't wiped  after each course.   So to begin with just get the Michelin service levels out of our minds.   Food is comparable to one to 2 Michelin stars.   We took the 8 course tasting menu.   Pricing was reasonable.

Went there for the pri fixe menu.  There were positives and negatives for the whole night.  First, we were seated in the solarium which was looked nice, but after being seated, we quickly noticed ants on our table.  After squashing 10 or so, it was clearly evident to the wait staff that we were not happy about the situation.  Dead ants on the table were noticeable and the staff offered no mitigation.  Not up to Ritz Level standards.  On the positive side, one in our party really didn't like the pri fixe menu and the chef made several substitutions of which all were delicious.  Back on the negative side the waiter we had had a very thick accent and we all strained to understand his English.  We eventually got there and this being Montreal there's nothing technically wrong with this, but at the price point and level of restaurant, I expect a waiter with impeccable English, and they could have switched our's out when there were issues and didn't.  I have been to other high end restaurants in Montreal with no issues. Unfortunately, the foie gras course was inedible to me and others at my table.  Several of us just ate a bite or two.  Now granted I am not a huge foie gras fan, but at this level of restaurant, I don't ever expect to gag at the table, which I did.  I would have also expected the staff to ask me if there was a problem.  Which I didn't get so unfortunate.Other courses were delivered at the high level service you would expect of this place.  For the price the over experience was sub par.

I had been looking forward to the visit when I first made travel plans and reservations. The visit did not disappoint; it was an all-around great experience. We were seated in the sun room overlooking the back courtyard. Snow had fallen all day and continued to fall during the meal so the evening had a tranquil cast to it. The room was separated from the rest of the restaurant; comfortable wood chairs and large tables populated this room with a casualness that reminded me of a ski chalet.As entrée, I had duck breast, a large portion, medium rare, served as large chunks with radicchio. The duck skin was crisp and crackled. It was perfect. Separately, we shared the potatoes (German Butterball) with truffles. Cooked to perfect consistency, the savory potatoes were garlicky well-seasoned, nutty, and delicious. We scraped ever last bit of the dish into our tummies. It was possibly the best potatoes I have ever had; the dish inspired me to improve my own version. I intend to purchase Chef Boulud's recently-released cookbook for other inspirations.Dessert was a chocolate/hazelnut crunch and separately, limoncello sorbet. I loved the two flavors together and am glad that it was a departure from the chocolate/raspberry combination offered at most places. Structural sugar element added taste, dimension (and wow) to the meal.Service was impeccable. Reminded me of the level of service received at Commander's Palace many, many moons ago. The waitstaff synchronized the delivery of the meal so that all the plates touched the table at the same time. It was like a waltz. I saw pride in their delivery; they knew that small details impress and make a lasting impression.
Wow. Loved it. If Michelin were in Canada, I'd be supportive of assigning them with one star.

I was staying at the Ritz and I arrived rather late so I decided to eat at the restaurant on the property. I got a seat at the bar and I must say, they were the most comfortable bar stools I have ever encountered. The atmosphere was intimate and luxe. The bartender was very friendly and helped me pick out a wine to enjoy as I am not that familiar with European wines. I was not wanting anything particularly heavy before bed but apparently heavy food is all you'll get here. I sort of let this affect my overall rating but only because I felt that some items were a bit misleading.I got the herb salad and the half order of the gnocchi. The herb salad was delicious but the entire bottom of the salad was thick, creamy cheese. It was good but there was more cheese than salad! There was also an egg of some sort, I am guessing quail. The gnocchi was delicious but the "coral emulsion" is a very heavy cream sauce. For just those two items and two glasses of wine, my total was over $100. I know people don't go to a restaurant like this to dine cheaply but I guess I just felt that what I ate wasn't that amazing. It was tasty but definitely not something I'd rave about.

Fancy brunch spot - beautiful space and garden - grub is just ok.  If you order the buffet, you'll practically get everything on the menu - but it is not that spectacular and pastries did not seem fresh.  The 2 eggs special with bacon or sausage was fine.  The goat cheese n fig quiche was a winner for the buffet.  I was expecting more from a Boulud resto. The Mimosas made the experience divine. Service was swift and everyone very accommodating. If you're feeling fancy after you've checked out of the Ritz, Boulud might fit your bill. However, it would probably be better to take an Uber to one of the many little bistros that this beautiful city has to offer.  Would I come back for a $200 brunch for 3? Prolly not , but I definitely see myself drinking mimosas in their garden again! Merci for that!

Excellent food, decor and service.  Best of four places we ate at in Montreal. Room is spectacular. Service is excellent.Three appetizers: tuna carpaccio, peppers and snow crab and other fresh stuff. Main courses Risotto with Morel mushrooms and truffles. Salmon with uni.

Very hard to find any complaint. Attention-to-detail in food and service was impeccable. Cocktails were on point and the wait staff was attentive and knowledgeable. From the humblest root vegetable to the glorious foie gras stuffed squab leg, everything was prepared with the greatest care and perfect technique. The dishes were creative and delicious. This was a great treat and a wonderful first meal in Montreal

Not worth the money.  Steak was grizzly for all 6 at table who had it.  Mushrooms were not good.  Service was so so.  Way over priced for what you get.   I did give a 3 because if it was at a normal spot I would say it was okay. But for this kind of price.  Not good.

Great service and amazing terrace where you can have an excellent Sunday brunch.You can get a buffet service or a la Carte, what I normally take If you love terraces, you definitely won't be disappointed

Ambience was great, classy, elegant and feels rich. Service was professional and top notch from the reception to the server. Not too intimidating, very knowledgable and professional overall. Food was not  French as expected, a notable Italian dishes were found on the menu given Chef Daniel Boulud concept is more towards classic French.However the taste for all dishes were great, well executed. Food presentation was classic, simple, nice and precise. Price wise it was on the expensive side, be ready to spend about $150 per person. It was worth it especially  for a special occasion. This was my second visit and it did not disappoint for sure.

3 appetizers + 3 main dishes + 2 desserts and one bottle of red (225$) = 725$ (tax + tips in) for 3 people. Was it worth it? Never. Was it good? Hell yeah! Would I recommend? Maybe. Am I being helpful? Maybe not. Why did I post this review? i honestly don't know.

I am sometimes disappointed by foodie restaurants...  If I'm going to pay this much for dinner, it better be amazing.  Maison Boulud did not disappoint.  We had the tasting menu (all at the table must partake) and they accommodated all of our food allergies so  at times, we had 3 different dishes for 4 people.  The service was excellent.  Our sommelier, Alex was very enthusiastic and knew his wine.   He recommended a very tasty Pinot Noir that went with most everything on our menu.  -cheese biscuit-like amuse bouche and creamy broth soup started our meal perfectly.  So much flavor in that soup - eat it slowly for full effect.  -baby chicken was cooked so tender and accompanied by tasty poached radishes.  -butternut ravioli with pancetta (?) and milk foam made me pause with my eyes closed, "mmmmm..." I muttered as a reflex. -my husband's venison was so tender and tasted like high end beef filet... I must admit I was nervous about venison but really liked trying some of the meat. -short ribs with sweet bread... I was never a fan of sweet breat - the thought of thymus or pancreas was just too unappetizing and the flavor was never good enough to keep me from thinking, "I'm eating thymus."  But Maison Bouloud has changed me into a sweetbread lover - perfectly seasoned and cooked that I actually ate the large piece on the plate and wanted more.  -My husband reported his sea urchin dish was okay - flavor was overpowering of fish so some people would probably really like this.  -dessert - beautiful creations of "stained-glass" candy on cream with tiny crisp meringues and fruit.  Not too heavy, which was perfect for a very filling foodie meal.  My husband was actually stuffed!Beautiful contemporary ambiance in the Ritz Carlton.
Great seafood. Oysters are always reliable. Best anchovies. Try breakfast - they have Montreal style bagels and excellent smoked salmon. For hotel guests that saves a trip to beauty's.

The chef spent some time in Asia, hence the reason for mentioning the creative touch. Anything you eat is pretty much spectacular. The ambiance is unique with very good service willing to help you decide. If anything I found it somewhat expensive, reason why I didn't rate it as excellent

We went here for a lunch on a beautiful sunny day and we had a good time overall. The atmosphere here is absolutely top notch, we were sitting close to the terrace and the view to the garden is gorgeous which we enjoy the most. The food we had are beef tartar, quails and Arctic char, nothing to complain about, just not as amazing as I would assume it would be. Maybe I'll return for a dinner to see if it's gonna be better.

It was good, honestly. Really good even. But not worth the price (and I am all in for an expensive meal if it. Is worth the experience. Maybe my expectations were too high. I had the brunch, tasted the eggs with truffle, tasted the burger (the bread was amazing). Speaking of bread, their selection is good too. Overall a great experience. I'll definitely try the supper menu and update my comment at a later date

We celebrated our anniversary in this restaurant while visiting Montreal. We had their tasting menu and I would rate the food 4 stars. The food was good but it it was really nothing special comparatively to other $$$$ sign with 8 course meal we had in US or other countries we had visited. I'm giving them 5 stars for their friendly service and for doing some nice touch by writing happy anniversary in our dessert and spreading rose petals on our table.

Ok, Montreal is supposed to be a French town, so I had high expectation for our dinner at Maison Boulud. We had the prix fixe menu on Christmas Eve--there were hits and misses. But I can honestly say, I've had better French food in Chicago than there. I liked my foie gras terrine, the sweetbread (crispy outside and well seasoned), and my husband's dessert (some blood orange sorbet). I didn't like my veal, and I REALLY didn't like my husband's steak--it's weird, they both looked well cooked, mine was medium and my husband's steak was medium rare--but both were really chewy. One of the worst meat course I've had. Next time we are in town, we'd still stay at the same hotel, but probably won't eat at this restaurant again.

Just finished a fabulous brunch today on a beautiful Sunday afternoon in Montreal. The reservation was for 130pm and the atmosphere was spectacular. Located right next to the Ritz Carlton hotel, the 2 of us were nestled in our own oasis with a pond and beautiful scenery (please see pic). Brunch is 39 dollars for 2 courses (app and main or main and dessert) or 49 for 3 courses. We went for 2 courses. To start we both had the baby beet salad, ruban blue fresh goat cheese, pistachios and watercress. Wow...what a salad. So fresh and each mouthful was heaven. Next up, I had the Louis d'Or stuffed agnolotti pasta, tarragon sweet peas and green asparagus. The pasta is housemade and again, wow...I didn't want it to end. My friend ordered the housemade smoked salmon and sunny side egg, potato latke, creme fraiche, red onions and capers. She seemed to really enjoy it! Great service, great food and amazing atmosphere. Worth checking out and make a reservation so that you can sit outside!

Located in the Ritz Carlton -- it's a very fancy place. The patio overlooks a very nicely landscaped garden. Food was good -- fresh ingredients, nice presentation, cooking brings out taste of ingredients rather than overwhelming palette with too much seasoning and herbs. Staff wasn't very friendly so gave 4 stars.

Perfect of course.  Yes, we had breakfast there every morning of our vacation as we were staying at the Ritz-Carlton, but we also had dinner there.  I'm experienced with the New York location Daniel as I live in New York, so I was enthusiastic to try the Montreal restaurant, and the atmosphere is much more laid back than the New York location.  Service was absolutely perfect, we shared 9 different dishes, our cocktails to start were lovely while we perused the wine list - we had 2 excellent bottles and everything was what we had hoped for, and more.  Some favorites includeD the Cornish hen, the crab dish, the foie gras of course, everything was just so delicious.  In addition, we were seated at what I felt was the best table, outdoors near the duck pond on such a beautiful evening.  Our experience could not have been better.  We will definitely be back next time we are in Montreal.

I was so excited to try this restaurant while in Montreal and it didn't disappoint! I was able to get a reservation for 8 pm on a Saturday night. We were seated outdoors facing a court yard that had a pond with ducks and a really beautiful view. The service here is impeccable. The server, sommelier and other workers are all so helpful and really know the menu. We started with the bluefin tuna carpaccio and this other starter that had uni, fluke crudo, and avocado wrapped crab. They were both delicious. I loved the fluke, especially because it was marinated so well. They each came with a type of cracker or chip. One was made with squid ink and rice flour. For entrees, I ordered the John Dory fillet. It came with cauliflower and potato in a potato purée. They were these clear potato chips on top, that were really cool looking. The dish was amazing. I loved it. My boyfriend had a halibut fillet that was cooked in Singapore curry and served with shrimp and clams. He also loved the flavor and enjoyed it very much. The food was great and the service was amazing. We had such an amazing experience at Maison Boulud!

This is one of the best restaurants I have dined at in MontrealWe cam here on a Weekend. We made reservations for a a Saturday night only 1 week in advance. The restaurant was busy, but not too packed. The staff was very nice and helpful.We ordered the tasting menu. It is a 6 course meal that was wonderful. I do not remember all the details of the courses, but I will try my best to describe1st course: Ceviche served with heart of palm,lemon and i think there were oranges in there as well. This was my favorite course. Very nice. Not your traditional ceviche, but a nice twist on it which was very tasty and a nice start2nd course: Snow crab served with razor clam salad, avocado and wasabi cream, and Rice Vinegar Jelly. Very good also... 3rd course: Homemade potato Gnocchi with Lobster, Leeks, Mushrooms and Coral Emulsion. This was my wife's favorite dish... I also loved it... was a tie between this and the ceviche for me 4th course: Halibut dish... not sure of what else was in it. 5th course: Beef Daily Cut, Beets, Spinach, Horseradish and Rosemary. 6th course: Honey Madeleine.Coconut & Grapefruit, Coconut Mousse, The madeleines were fantastic and a must. There were no disappointments. All the served dishes were excellent. Will definitely repeatIt is a little expensive, but definitely worth the extra money. A great place for special occasions

The Cosmo de l'Orient is the best cocktail you'll have in the city. It's lovely to come in the summer and sit outside but the indoor atmosphere is still great. Other than that this restaurant doesn't meet the standard you'd expect. I've had pretty good meals and just OK ones. It would be nice if there was a bit more consistency.

Upon reading the comments from other Yelpers, I feel I didn't make the best choice from the menu when I went to Maison Boulud. It was a convenient option for me while I was staying in Montreal (nice when the restaurant is in the hotel!). I ordered a rigatoni pasta with alfredo sauce. It was pretty good and I was told the pasta was made fresh which is always a highlight - but oddly I don't think it tasted much different from pre-made pasta. The sauce was quite good but really buttery (make no mistake - I love butter, but twenty minutes into eating my dish I felt the once liquidy sauce started to solidify and at that point it tasted almost exclusively of butter). I felt the dish was missing something - chicken, vegetables perchance? Something to elevate it from simply pasta with a sauce. What I am seeing from the rest of the reviews is that Boulud's protein dishes are divine - which makes me think that next time a burger or a steak if where I should venture. The pictures of the beautifully-presented desserts also look enticing. Given I had a decent experience the first time at Boulud, I'm open to giving it another chance. Until next time, Maison Boulud!

Hi!I am from Montreal, a total foodie and love to frequent the city's best restaurants. I booked Boulud for my partner and I's anniversary last Saturday evening. It was my third time frequenting Boulud. In the past I had very lovely dining experiences here. This experience, however, left me completely perplexed and underwhelmed by the quality of service and ambiance. First off, we were seated on their terrasse area - however because it is autumn, it was cold. We were seated in a corner, which was surrounded by a white nylon tarp/tent and awful bright LED strip lighting. This was very underwhelming setting for a restaurant of this caliber. It felt like high end food served in a hotel lobby, quite touristy. Next was the service, which was questionable. The wait staff was snappy, rude and inconsistent. Not helpful. The food was good but due to the overall vibe, we already had a bad taste in our mouths. It felt and looked like a cheap hotel lobby restaurant. Good food does not justify poor ambiance and bad staff. I really wish I had a better experience this time! There are MANY excellent restaurants in Montreal and for the quality of experience I received, I would unfortunately not return back to Boulud.

3.5 stars rounding up to 4 for brunch.I am a little torn about this review. The food here deserves a solid 5 stars. Monsieur Boulud lives up to his reputation and I have yet to be disappointed by his food. (LOVE Daniel in NY) The presentation, taste and creativity of his food is amazing. We thoroughly enjoyed our food here. It was delicious!What I found surprising was the service. We frequent the Ritz(s) back at home - San Francisco, Half Moon Bay, Marina Del Rey, Lake Tahoe and have gotten used to a standard of service that I didn't quite find here in Montreal. We, by no means, had terrible service, but we didn't have great service either. It was the little things...my mimosa was forgotten, my silverware was forgotten so I had to ask for a set after my food arrived, our waters weren't refilled...it was just not something I expected to happen here at the Ritz. On the other hand, the gentleman in the front who fetched our coats for us was great so we at least left on a happy note.The Ritz is beautiful though. Next time, we'll have to come try the champagne bar and afternoon tea.Food:Crispy fried egg with ham and marinated mushrooms - perfectly balanced with the sweetness of the mushrooms and the saltiness of the ham and creaminess and crunchiness of the egg. Really tasty!Greek yogurt and berries - berries were sweet and the yogurt was thick and creamyEggs Benedict - the man friend had no complaints. He doesn't usually like eggs benedict but loved this.Skate wing - beautiful presentation and incredibly tasty. The skate wing was a little bit crispy outside and moist inside. Loved it!!Mini Madeleines - these were sooo good...I couldn't stop eating them. They came out warm with powdered sugar on top. Light and fluffy with a little zing of lemon. Addicting!

I went for brunch on two separate occasions a saturday and a sunday. Both times I was incredibly happy with the quality of the food and the service. The lobster roll was one of the best I have ever had in my life. It is a little pricey so I would save this place for a special occasion.
A great Boulud!!!Fantastic restaurant - food was amazing, staff friendly and knowledgeable, ambiance greatTotally recommend!

Service is impeccable. They went out of their way to accommodate my pregnant wife, making her a new amuse bouche from scratch (it was a Valentine's Day meal). There are no flaws to speak of in the food, it's well executed with no missteps. Would definitely recommend this restaurant for a special night

I had dinner yesterday with my daughter for the first time at Maison Boulud and I can say it is a very good place in the Ritz Carlton in Montreal : the ambience is very warm and welcoming besides having an astonishing decoration very trendy and luxurious , the service excellent , the food is excellent we had the entrees one of crudités and one of the cheese burrata which were very tasty and we had very well made drinks of martinis , then the main dishes one of gnocchi with lobster and mine was of fish Saint Pierre : I can say it was excellent made by a very good chef , I was really thrilled by the dinner and will sure come back .

I had a great time at this Boloud!The ambiance is refined yet friendly.I wasn't entirely sure about the idea of eating by myself smack dab in the middle of the restaurant, so the staff ushered me to their private room with a view of the kitchen. It was great!I ordered the  three course, late night supper menu. The complimentary arancini in squid ink was quite alright: tiny bite sized morsels to whet one's appetite. While the poricini soup was very seasonal, it looked unfortunately, but understandably, muddy brown. I quite enjoyed its earthy yet delicate flavors. I really enjoyed the lamb main course: succulent and tender and paired really well with refreshing, grilled vegetables. I rounded off my meal with a palette enriching cheese plate.The glasses of Chianti I ordered complimented the meal very well.I will admit that different servers bringing different courses felt a bit unnecessary. However, all of them were very polite and engaged me in friendly conversation. At the end of the evening, I was satiated and in a good spirits. I'll be back!

This is my 100th review on Yelp, which shows that I`m either dedicated or wasted a lot of time. Mr Moderator, do I get a prize such as a Yelp mug or a medal?! ;)My wife and I recently celebrated our wedding anniversary at Maison Boulud. At the end of the meal, we both agreed that Maison Boulud is one of, if not the best fine dining restaurant in Montreal. This is grand hotel dining of the highest order.We had outdoor seating and thoroughly enjoyed the urban garden along with the duck pond (I've had an inexplicable fondness for ducks since I was a child). We had the tasting menu, which consisted of 2 appetizers, 1 pasta, 1 fish, 1 meat and 2 desserts. My personal favorites were the cured Japanese snapper appetizer, the Wagyu beef tataki, a lamb dish (quality of the meat was unreal)... and the addictive madeleine at the end of the meal. The service is outstanding, yet not intimidating (as opposed to similar restaurants). The bill was a bit stiff but totally worth it considering the amazing meal we had. Will definitely return on the next special occasion.

My family decided to have brunch here on a Saturday. It was my first time at Maison Boulud so I was pretty stoked to try it. Good : The service was exceptional. Honestly, the hospitality is above anything I've experienced, everything from the hostess to waiters is very polite. My glass was constantly refilled, unbelievable good service. The decor was beautiful, we were seated outdoors and the garden was gorgeous (until my mom pointed out 'Look at all those dirty looking buildings behind it!). For appetizers, I've ordered the veal carpaccio and it was delicious. I had the trout as my main, and it was hands down the best fish I've ever had. Basically, every dish I picked was a hit!Bad : Everyone else's food.  My mom ordered a Croissant de Chez Hofkelsten Farci, which is a fancy name for soggy croissant with way too much cheese. My sister had the Ouefs Muerette, which translates to boring eggs benedict in English. My father ordered the DBGB Burger, which he never mentioned if it was good or not. Bottom line: I've sampled their plates as well and concluded that is very subpar for the price. Location is nice, the decor is stunning, but I wasn't blown away by any other dish...except the trout.

Creative, fresh ingredients and freshly designed works of culinary art.  The flavors are derived and cherished from the ingredients not added just by salt, sweet or fat.   The presentation and service is perfect with a great wine and cocktail list.  The Prunes and Peaches desert is a must have, delicate desert.  By the way, the pastry chief is an All Canada first place winner for his creations.  Their tea infusions are terrific.   The interior is elegant but not over done.  The furniture is comfortable, well maintained and the atmosphere is airy and very suitable for a business dinner or a romantic night out.   If you are coupling it get a window seat looking out on to the lovely park that the restaurant circles.  There is a nesting of while geese in the small pond that adds a lovely center piece.   Considering the resto is in the middle of downtown Montreal it is a peaceful place to enjoy a couple of hours of culinary bliss.   I see that the cost rating is $$$$ but realistically you are not spending much more than if you went to Baton Rouge BUT you are receiving a world class meal in a lovely, peaceful paradise.

You gotta eat here. Yes it's pricey, yes they will take their sweet time bringing out everything but you will have consumed one of the best meals of your life which will lead you into thinking about how to earn more money and eat every month here (I watched Narcos a few times). But even if you wanted to indulge that one special time then this place is perfect. Menu does change regularly from what I can see as others have posted here.

This very posh restaurant is located in the Ritz Carlton Montreal. The decor inside is contemporary, trendy, and elegant. There are walls of cut glass squares decorating the main rooms with a large fireplace in the center. My family and I were seated in a dining area that was private, we believe because Daniel in NYC catered my wedding 2 years ago and the recognized our name in their system.  It was a nice touch. We had to wait 10-15 minutes to get any menus but after that the service was impeccable. Our bread was replaced the second we finished it, our water was constantly filled, if our wine was empty more was brought out. There was a special menu for Christmas which had a pretty good variety of options. My husband and I settled on the raviolo for a starter. It was one very marge ravioli filled with cheese and spinach and a poached egg, topped with leeks and mushrooms, in a parmesan foam and pesto sauce. It was pretty flavorful and good but we both agreed we would have liked the sauce to be a bit thicker so we could have eaten it more easily with the raviolo. My fathered ordered the mushroom soap with foie gras and he loved it. My ordered the foie gras and also enjoyed it throughly. There was not a vegetarian option on the menu for the entree but they gladly made me a mushroom, tomato, squash pasta with a mushroom cream sauce. It was quite good. My husband got a pasta with duck ragout. He basically inhaled it he loved it so much. My mom got a fish entree and raved Bout it all through dinner and after. My dad got the steak duo and really liked it but had trouble finishing it because it was just a lot of steak. We all shared the four desserts. They were very delicious and incredibly interesting. The sorbets and ice creams were paired perfectly with the flavors of the desserts. This was a very nice meal. The staff was accommodating and very attentive. They were also very knowledgable regarding wines and each dish on the menu. They were constantly seeing if everything was alright with our meal. At the end, we were given a small basket of madeleines which we ended up taking home with us.
I had the three course tasting menu on New Years Eve and it was amazing! Delicious food, portion sizes on point and excellent service and ambiance!

We (2 adults) walked in on a Sunday morning around 8:30 for breakfast before our flight home.  At first he hostess said they don't take any non hotel guests for breakfast.  The place only had maybe 5 tables occupied.  I said we had to be out in an hour anyways to get to the airport and they accommodated.  We sat on the nice back patio.  The scenery and seating was nice.  The garden is really pretty with 5 ducks swimming around.  We did a la carte.  I got the dejeuner fermier with scrambled eggs, a sausage, and a montreal bagel.  It was very filling and good.  My husband had the eggs bennie and he enjoyed it.  They could have filled my OJ a little more without me asking for a refill.  Nice for a quiet Sunday breakfast.

Had Sunday brunch with friends. Ordered the 3 serving menu for fifty something bucks. It was worth every penny. I have to give it to French chefs, the experience at this restaurant is so unique that it makes prices irrelevant on the menu. Example, waiter takes order, another person serves basket of bread, another person serves water, dishes are served simultaneously without asking who ordered what, soiled cutlery is removed and new ones brought for every dish, bread basket and water replenished without asking, you basically feal like royalty eating here. I haven't even spoken about the presentation and care taken in preparing every single dish which are as savoury as pieces of art. Its an overwhelming and other wordly experience to eat at Maison Boulud, an experience that everyone must try at least once.

Pretty much what you would expect from a Boulud property - great service, elegant atmosphere and creative food. Not as hardcore on the dress code as Daniel in NYC, which is great (but I suppose to be expected being that it's located in a hotel).A couple unique items on the menu which is a breath of fresh air; so many restaurants seem to feature the same trendy items these days.Overall a great night out. Some proper cocktails, well shucked oysters, a fantastic Barolo by the glass, and some creative, well conceived and well prepared food.

Overall this is a nice restaurant. The wine was good that they introduce. The appetizer is a very small portion. The main course tastes very good. The service was very good. But it took hour and a half to get the main dish on the table. Price is ok for a restaurant like this.

We decided to try Maison Boulud for their Menu Table d'Hôte, which is available as 2 or 3 courses during weekday lunch hours. The 2-course menu is $38, and 3-course menu $45. We reserved for a table of 2 at 1pm through Opentable.Even before ordering, our waiter brought out house bread and warm butter to enjoy. There was classic French baguette and house focaccia that was really yummy. As for our menu, we chose to have the 3-course (appetizer, main, dessert):Me - petit pea soup, trout, chocolate and salted caramel (I forgot the names of the dishes.. :()Hubby - salmon tartare, beef bourguignon, and raspberry mousse cake with pistachios.There are 3 options for each course you can choose from.I actually only ordered the soup because I was cold from walking outside and because I didn't want to order the same salmon tartare as my hubby. The only other option was to get their salad which I wasn't really for.  The soup was rather large in portion, as it was served in a very deep soup bowl, and the colour of the soup was very pretty. It was refreshing to see the colour green, as I wasn't able to see much of it outside in Montreal yet! If you don't like peas, this won't be for you, as you can really taste the natural flavours of the peas very strongly. Inside the soup were small crouton? like bits that kept its crisp until the very last moment in where it entered my mouth. I was very surprised to see that they were not soggy at all while they swam around in my soup. Overall, the soup was well enjoyed and I wouldn't mind reordering it again.Hubby's salmon tartare was also quite large in portion as well, which was quite surprising because we were more used to smaller portions of tartare. For what you pay ($38 or $45), the portions were generous. It made me wonder how their dinner portions are: are they similar? Or larger? The soft salmon was balanced out by the thin crisp on the top along with leafy greens, and the roasted beets brought out more of the chewing texture of the dish. Underneath the salmon tartare was the sauce that brought the appetizer all together; the savoury sauce had sharp tanginess to it that aimed to balance out the blandness of the salmon. Although the textures were well balanced, the flavours, on the other hand, weren't and the ingredients didn't come together in synchrony unless the hidden sauce was well mixed into the tartare; we were able to taste each ingredient on its own, individually, even though there were other factors eaten together.My seafood dish looked very appealing at first glance, and I was delighted that they had seafood on their lunch menu. The main trout was cooked very well, not overdone, soft and delicate in texture. Underlying all the ingredients was the main sauce that was generally too overpowering. For dessert, I chose the most chocolate-y one; I love salted caramel and vanilla bean anything, so this dessert was a must order for me. The dessert intrigued my fascination about chocolate; I had never tried chocolate that had texture like this before! It was more like soft fudge, but not too soft that it doesn't keep its shape or melt. If there was one thing that I didn't like about the dessert was that it was dark chocolate. Now, the dark chocolate went very well with salted caramel, and even my hubby, who doesn't like very sweet things, actually really enjoyed my dessert and preferred it over his!Overall, our first visit to Maison Boulud was enjoyable. The service was great: all of our orders were correct, on time, and warm. Our waiter kept our glasses full, and he was polite and quick. The atmosphere of the restaurant divides into two, as you could be seated in the veranda or the main dining hall which is more formal. We sat in the veranda which was very nice because it had lots of natural sunlight coming in which I really liked. As many hotel restaurants are, the washrooms are not within the restaurant but in the hotel lobby. The food was okay, as there were dishes that we really liked, and some that we didn't as much. Generally, Maison Boulud is a place we would personally come with family for brunch, but I don't think we will be back anytime soon because it didn't really give us the WOW factor that we expect for a fine dining experience. Perhaps our lunch experience was an outlier, as Maison Boulud was picked #27 in Canada's Top 100 Best Restaurants! Maybe dinner is a better time to go.

Let me just say the restuarant was amazing! We went Sunday & we started out w/ an 8 course meal.  truly superb! So, we decided to make another reservation for our kids to enjoy the experience.. tonight on a Wednesday service started out great but then we notice our waitress was no where to be found! It took us about 35 min to get another drink & she never checked on us period! As soon as she got our dinner entre in & that was it.. So, my hubby had complain stating is anyone going to take our order or refill for our kids / our drinks too.. We looked over & the hostess got the waitress attention & let her know the situation..  We thought she will be right over but no it took her about 10 more min to even notice there was a situations.. Eating at a fine dining restaurant the food / service / ambiance should be perfect.. we spent over $700 dollars which we thought wasn't a great experience.  My husband was so pissed & he left the restuarant for a walk to cool himself down. At least of all things the waitress should of apologize to us for not caring..
Tasting menu with the wine pairing was delicious. The staff was professional and well trained. Highest quality in the city.

Glorious wine selection and divine food inspired by a great chef! The variety of options to choose from will definitely satisfy whatever craving you may have. The service is beyond fantastic and your order will always be served with the utmost perfection in mind.I'm a big fan of their Tropezienne Salad, Lamb Ravioli, and mouthwatering, perfectly cooked seafood (Salmon, Scallops, and Cod).Elegant, classy, creative, passionate and unique are just a few words to describe this gem at the Ritz Carlton! They have a beautiful garden in the back, with ducks quacking around the pond and the most relaxing ambiance.
Best restaurant I've ever been too, very friendly and fancy . The food was to die for . Would definitely come back for a special occasion !
